metadata.titleEn: Quantitative temperature and monsoon precipitation data sets for the past 5000 years in northern China
metadata.description: In this study, the beilianchi lake of Liupanshan in the Loess Plateau of northern China was selected to quantitatively reconstruct the high resolution (~ 30yr) warm season temperature series of northern China in the past 5000 years based on the gdgts index and the fitting equation established by reanalysis of global lake surface sediment gdgts data. In the past 5000 years, the overall temperature in northern China showed a downward trend, in which the temperature of 3000 bc-200 ad decreased slowly by ~ 0.5 ℃ and then decreased rapidly by ~ 4 ℃ after 200 ad, accompanied by four Millennium scale cold events of 2-3 ℃. At the same time, we reconstructed the monsoon precipitation changes since the middle late Holocene by using the single hydrogen isotope in the same borehole sediments. The monsoon precipitation in northern China showed a downward trend in the past 5000 years, accompanied by three obvious 100 year scale strong precipitation drought fluctuations.

background: High-quality paleoclimate reconstructions can provide crucial climate context to test the hypothesis of climatic impact on historical culture changes. The Chinese civilization is the oldest and most enduring in the world. During its long lasting “5000-year” history, China has experienced a series of centennial-scale rise and fall of dynasties, unifications and divisions, war and peace. Climate changes have long been proposed as an important driver of these historical cultural changes. One of the important reasons for these inconsistent and even contradictory conclusions is the shortage of robust quantitative climate reconstructions, especially in the heartland of Chinese culture. Furthermore, high-resolution and reliable temperature records covering the “5000-year” Chinese history are quite lacking for the heartland of Chinese culture. The Chinese Loess Plateau (CLP) is located near the present northwestern margin of East Asian summer monsoon, which is also a transition zone between semi-humid and semi-arid and the farming-pastoral ecotone of north China. Over the past decade, a large number of monsoon precipitation records in the CLP have been reconstructed, some of them can present reliable precipitation changes for the past 5000 years of Chinese history. Unfortunately, reliable temperature records are still limited, in particular most available records are qualitative rather than quantitative reconstructions. Branched glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers (brGDGTs) are membrane-spanning lipids produced by heterotrophic bacteria containing two C28 alkyl chains with 4e6 methyl substituents and 0e2 cyclopenthy moieties. Because the bacteria can produce more/less methyl branches to adjust to colder/warmer conditions, and thus brGDGTs have been proposed as a novel proxy for quantitative temperature reconstructions in terrestrial settings such as soils, peats and lakes over the past decade.
research objective: Here we report high-resolution and quantitative temperature and precipitation records covering the entire “5000-year” Chinese history in northern China. We aim (1) to provide a quantitative climate background for Chinese dynasties, and (2) to show the coincidence in the timing between abrupt cold and/or dry events and large-scale social unrests and southern migration of nomads.
challenges: One of the important reasons for these inconsistent and even contradictory conclusions is the shortage of robust quantitative climate reconstructions, especially in the heartland of Chinese culture. As a result, many studies have to use broad or even hemispheric-scale temperature data to evaluate its impact on Chinese cultural changes, which probably increase the uncertainty of the relation between them.
methods: In December 2013, a 6.67-m-long sediment core BLC13B was drilled from the lake center at a water depth of ~4 m using a Piston Corer on a UWITEC platform. The sediment cores were subsampled at every 1-cm interval, and seven terrestrial plant macrofossils were analyzed by accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) at Beta Laboratory (Zhang et al., 2019a). A total of 20 surface samples, including 9 lake surface sediments and 11 surface soils, and 171 downcore samples from core BLC13B were analyzed for GDGTs following the chemical pretreatment (Feng et al., 2019). Each sediment sample from core BLC13B was freeze-dried and homogenized before being pretreated for GDGTs. 3-5 g sediment samples were ultrasonically extracted using dichloromethane: methanol (9:1, v/v, 15 min, 4°C). The total lipids were concentrated with N2 gas and saponified for more than 12 h with 6% KOH in methanol solution. The neutral lipids were extracted using n-hexane four times and then separated into apolar and polar fractions through silica gel column chromatography by n-hexane and MeOH, respectively. The polar fraction, containing the GDGTs, was filtered through a 0.45mm PTFE filter before analysis. GDGTs were analyzed using the improved chromatographic procedure with full separation of 5- and 6-methyl isomers, by HPLC-APCI-MS (Shimadzu LCeMS 8030) equipped with two coupled Inertsil SIL-100A silica columns (each 250 mm x 4.6 mm, 3µm; GL sciences Inc.) at the Institute of Earth Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences (Wang et al., 2016).
dataset: The age-depth model indicates the core spans the last 5000 years with a mean sedimentation rate of ~0.13 cm/yr (Fig. S2; Zhang et al., 2019a).
findings: Our data not only provide a more complete climate background for Chinese dynasties, but show the coincidence in the timing between abrupt cold and/or dry events and large-scale social unrests and southern migration of nomads. This finding reveals climate fluctuations, in particular variations in temperature, played an important role in affecting Chinese historical cultural changes.

Definition.Question: What does 'brGDGTs' mean in the context of paleoclimate reconstruction?
Definition.Answer: Branched glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers (brGDGTs) are membrane-spanning lipids produced by heterotrophic bacteria. They contain two C28 alkyl chains with 4 to 6 methyl substituents and 0 to 2 cyclopentyl moieties. These bacteria adjust the number of methyl branches in response to colder or warmer conditions, making brGDGTs a novel proxy for quantitative temperature reconstructions in terrestrial settings such as soils, peats, and lakes.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'quantitative climate reconstructions' in historical climate studies?
Definition.Answer: Quantitative climate reconstructions refer to the process of using scientific data and analysis to produce precise and measurable estimates of past climate conditions, such as temperature and precipitation, over a defined period. These reconstructions provide detailed climate context necessary for understanding historical cultural changes, particularly in regions like the Chinese Loess Plateau.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using GDGTs for climate reconstruction in northern China compare to traditional paleoclimate reconstruction methods?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection method using GDGTs involves analyzing branched glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers from sediment samples, which allows for quantitative temperature reconstructions. Traditional methods may rely more on qualitative proxies or broader scale data, which could introduce more uncertainty in the reconstructions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using GDGTs versus using broad hemispheric-scale temperature data for studying the impact of climate on historical cultural changes?
Comparison.Answer: Using GDGTs as a novel proxy faces challenges such as ensuring robust quantitative reconstructions specific to the region, whereas using broad hemispheric-scale temperature data might introduce uncertainties due to its lack of specificity and relevance to the local climate impacts on historical cultural changes.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of a sediment core from a lake compare to other potential sources of paleoclimate data, such as tree rings or ice cores, in terms of data resolution and reliability?
Comparison.Answer: The use of a sediment core from a lake provides high-resolution (~30yr) data and allows for quantitative reconstructions using GDGTs, which can be more precise than some qualitative methods. In contrast, tree rings or ice cores may offer different timescales and resolutions but could be less effective in certain regions like the Loess Plateau where specific local data is needed.

Interpretation.Question: How do the methods used for sediment core analysis, including the chemical and chromatographic procedures, contribute to the reliability and resolution of temperature and precipitation reconstructions?
Interpretation.Answer: The detailed chemical pretreatment and chromatographic procedures ensure that GDGTs are accurately extracted and analyzed, producing high-resolution quantitative data. The use of specialized equipment, such as HPLC-APCI-MS, and the careful preparation of samples contribute significantly to the reliability and precision of the climate reconstructions in the dataset.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes limitations in quantitative climate reconstructions, especially in regions that are significant to cultural history?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: One of the important reasons for limitations in quantitative climate reconstructions, particularly in culturally significant regions like the heartland of Chinese culture, is the shortage of robust data. This shortage forces many studies to rely on broader or hemispheric-scale temperature data, which may increase the uncertainty of the relationship between climate and cultural changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to obtain high-resolution temperature records for the past 5000 years in certain regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge in obtaining high-resolution temperature records for the past 5000 years in regions such as the Chinese Loess Plateau is due to the limited availability of reliable temperature records. Most existing records are qualitative rather than quantitative, which hampers the ability to provide precise climate reconstructions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for novel proxies in terrestrial temperature reconstructions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for novel proxies in terrestrial temperature reconstructions arises because existing records are often qualitative and lack the robustness required for quantitative analysis. Branched glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers (brGDGTs) have been proposed as a novel proxy because they can provide more accurate quantitative temperature reconstructions, adjusting to varying climatic conditions over terrestrial settings such as soils, peats, and lakes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing GDGTs as a proxy for quantitative temperature reconstructions in paleoclimate studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing GDGTs can provide novel and quantitative temperature reconstructions in terrestrial settings like soils, peats, and lakes, which may lead to more robust climate context for historical cultural change analysis, particularly in regions with previously limited reliable temperature records.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the lack of robust quantitative climate reconstructions affect the interpretation of climate's impact on historical cultural changes in northern China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The shortage of robust quantitative climate reconstructions could lead to increased uncertainty in determining the relationship between climate changes and historical cultural shifts, possibly resulting in inconsistent or contradictory conclusions regarding the causality of climatic impacts on social dynamics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the age-depth model constructed to determine the sedimentation rate and time span of a sediment core?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The age-depth model is constructed using accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) analysis of terrestrial plant macrofossils. These analyses provide chronological data points that are used to develop a model depicting the sedimentation rate and time span. For the sediment core mentioned, the model indicates the core spans the last 5000 years with a mean sedimentation rate of ~0.13 cm/yr.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the collection of high-resolution quantitative temperature and precipitation data over the past 5000 years in the Chinese Loess Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as high-performance liquid chromatography-atmospheric pressure chemical ionization-mass spectrometry (HPLC-APCI-MS) have enabled the precise analysis of branched glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers (brGDGTs), providing high-resolution quantitative temperature reconstructions.

Enablement.Question: How do modern chemical pretreatment methods enhance the extraction and analysis of GDGTs from sediment cores for paleoclimate reconstruction?
Enablement.Answer: Modern chemical pretreatment methods, involving ultrasonic extraction and chromatographic procedures, enable the effective extraction and separation of GDGTs from sediment cores, allowing for detailed analysis and more accurate paleoclimate reconstructions.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the use of accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) contribute to the development of an age-depth model for sediment cores spanning 5000 years?
Enablement.Answer: Accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) is used to analyze terrestrial plant macrofossils within sediment cores, providing precise radiocarbon dating that contributes to the development of accurate age-depth models for sediment cores spanning 5000 years.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset focusing on quantitative climate reconstruction in the heartland of Chinese culture face challenges in achieving robust and reliable results?
Expectation.Answer: One of the important reasons for inconsistent and even contradictory conclusions is the shortage of robust quantitative climate reconstructions in the heartland of Chinese culture. Many studies have to use broad or even hemispheric-scale temperature data, which probably increases the uncertainty of the relation between climate changes and cultural impacts.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have when using GDGTs as a proxy for quantitative temperature reconstructions, and why might these expectations not always be met?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers expect GDGTs to serve as a novel proxy for quantitative temperature reconstructions because the bacteria producing them can adjust methyl branches according to temperature changes. However, expectations might not always be met due to potential variations in bacterial response or environmental factors not accounted for in the proxy's calibration.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges faced in ensuring the robustness and accuracy of temperature reconstructions using brGDGTs in paleoclimate studies?
Judgmental.Answer: One potential challenge is the shortage of robust quantitative climate reconstructions, particularly in key historical regions. The methodology of using brGDGTs needs careful calibration and validation with modern analogs to ensure accuracy. The complexity of brGDGT production in varying environmental conditions may also introduce uncertainties, requiring meticulous methodological rigor.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the use of GDGTs can result in quantitative temperature reconstructions for the past 5000 years.
Assertion.Answer: GDGTs, or glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers, are membrane-spanning lipids produced by heterotrophic bacteria. These bacteria can produce more or fewer methyl branches to adjust to colder or warmer conditions, making GDGTs a novel proxy for quantitative temperature reconstructions in terrestrial settings. The study used a global dataset of lake surface sediments to establish a calibration equation that allows for high-resolution temperature reconstructions over the past 5000 years.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges involved in creating a robust quantitative climate reconstruction over such a long historical period.
Assertion.Answer: One of the significant challenges is the shortage of robust quantitative climate reconstructions, particularly in the heartland of Chinese culture. Many studies rely on broad or hemispheric-scale temperature data, which can increase uncertainty when evaluating the impact of climate on cultural changes. Achieving high-resolution and reliable temperature records over 5000 years involves overcoming these limitations and using proxies like GDGTs for quantitative reconstructions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methodologies used for extracting high-resolution temperature and precipitation records over the past 5000 years in northern China, focusing on the use of GDGTs.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies involved drilling a sediment core from a lake and analyzing GDGTs extracted from these sediments. The sediments were subsampled at every 1-cm interval, and the GDGTs were analyzed using HPLC-APCI-MS with chromatographic procedures ensuring full separation of isomers. The sediment samples underwent chemical pretreatment, including ultrasonic extraction, lipid concentration, and saponification, followed by separation and filtration before analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the challenges encountered in creating robust quantitative paleoclimate reconstructions for Chinese cultural heartlands and suggest potential improvements.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the shortage of robust quantitative climate reconstructions and reliance on broad or hemispheric-scale data which increases the uncertainty in understanding climate impacts on cultural changes. Improvements could involve obtaining more localized, high-resolution climate data and enhancing techniques for accurate temperature reconstructions using innovative proxies like brGDGTs.
